The dog that isn't barking: no recent news that I could find. As I found when defending myself pro se in a multimillion $ lawsuit against me, delay is the friend of the innocent. Delay enabled me to persuade one lawyer after another for the plaintiff to beg the judge to be allowed to quit. After the plaintiff got a bad enough reputation that she no longer could find a new sucker, er, lawyer, it was trivial for me to win a judgment againsther. I see something  similar in Waymo v Uber. Delay strengthens Waymo as Uber's management troubles proliferate and the reality of Uber's overall criminality becomes clearer. Delay long enough, and Uber's reconstituted management will settle. Or else Uber will implode, which would clear out one of Waymo's most serious competitors. Indeed, this lawsuit is an excellent vehicle for ferreting out Uber's deep dark secrets, and for inspiring Federal prosecutors to go after it and its managers.
They will likely settle in order to not drag out a court case and open even more information to the public.
The overwhelming portion of lawsuits are settled  rahter than going to trial. Juries are unpredictable and rational corporate leaders don't gamble on that sort of casino.

"Uber's voluntary disclosure of a year-old hack that exposed the personal data of 57 million drivers and customers could be taken as a sign that under new Chief Executive Officer Dara Khosrowshahi, the company is changing its ways. But no, Uber's biggest problem is still its culture of dishonesty -- something the leadership change hasn't fundamentally altered.
By making public the hacking case Uber's CEO does seem to be trying to clean up Uber's bad practices, so I will stick to the thought that the Waymo case will also need to be resolved.

The judges ruling seems to be only relevant to the amount of damages, not to the validity of Waymo's case. It is set back, but if the amounts of damages is less certain it could make it easier for Uber to try and settle. The amount of damages involved (between $1b and $2b) seem quite small compared to the price that Softbank is paying for Uber shares (valueing Uber at between $50b and $68b).
Several decisions by Alsip this week have seriously damaged the case, including Waymo's expert witness being thrown out. So I'm going to substantially downgrade my forecast.

Three factors influencing my downgrade. Uber hired new general counsel. The timeline is making me a bit more nervous upon reflection. Also, I read some statistics on the success of trade secrets at the federal level that suggested that macro-level success rates are variable, but in the range of 30-70%ish (Almeling et al., 2009).  As you can see, I'm sitting well above the upper band of that probability. I want the macro-trends to impact this judgment. As justification for my using federal data to inform a state decision, I note that California was one of the states listed in the study that is most frequently cited in federal trade secrets cases.

CORPORATE GOVERNANCE
not for 12 to 18 months

Uber  has hired a new top legal officer who will begin working next mont.  Tony West's experience as a former federal prosecutor and a senior Department of Justice official while Barack Obama was US president make him "well equipped to handle the investigations into our past practices," according to Khosrowshahi.  West will be starting the same month a trial is to begin in a civil suit filed by Waymo . 
West is coming from Pepsi, not a law firm.

New report suggests that two trials may be necessary. If that's true, it would complicate the timeline. But, none of the existing reporting has stated that the schedule *will* be changed or that a second trial will occur. Thus, a small downgrade from my last 90%. I'm waiting on more information before making a bigger readjustment.

Question is when will settlement happen.

As a first pass, looked up how many lawsuits end in settlements, apparently it's around 90-95% both in general and for IP lawsuits specifically. In the absence of other forecasts I would start at 90%. But, seeing that the consensus here is much lower than that, I expect that when I learn more about this specific case I'll find reasons to downgrade that estimate; I may as well downgrade it in advance. Will update as I learn more.

I listened to the oral arguments. Waymo seemed to convincingly argue that Uber was not a signatory to the contract that Levandowski signed. And, it appears that Uber's entire argument hinges on that contract applying to Uber. It seems unlikely that the court would transfer the terms of that contract to Uber. The only way I could see this being decided the other way would be if Uber's claim is upheld that they had to have knowledge that this intellectual property brought to their company was obtained by inappropriate means. Despite that, one of the judges was still suggesting alternative arguments to the original plaintiff as if to say there are many avenues to a decision in favor of the plaintiff in this case. The weight of all of this information points to an answer in the affirmative for this question.

Cursory glance suggests that trade secrets settlements aren't uncommon, Uber's parent company appears at cursory glance to be financially stable, and the question offers several paths toward an affirmative answer (settlement or found liable). The time also seems reasonable to reach a settlement agreement or resolution to the case, though it is short. Additionally, no liability requirement is necessary.
I think the court will find for Waymo.

Uber has operated on the edge of, or beyond the law; no need to list the issues it has. The new CEO Khosrowshahi was presumably hired to sort it out because the board thought that Uber's current operating model was never going to produce a return on investment. It would not be an unreasonable approach for a new CEO to attempt to clear up all the issues that are threatening Uber, these presumably would include dealing with Uber's culture, treatment of staff, treatment of drivers, relationship with public transport regulators and the Waymo case.

Open request to delay the trial which puts the timeline in jeopardy. If it goes to trial in October 10th, would push the likelihood of the jury awarding to Waymo over 50% given the strength of the evidence on Google's side.

I'm staying on the up-side of 50% until the trial actually starts, however, as it seems that deals often go right down to the wire.

See 
 "The Uber Hub in London. Transport for London, which regulates ride-hailing services in the city, said the company’s “approach and conduct demonstrate a lack of corporate responsibility.”
The Uber Hub in London. Transport for London, which regulates ride-hailing services in the city, said the company’s “approach and conduct demonstrate a lack of corporate responsibility.” Andrew Testa for The New York Times
By Amie Tsang and Michael J. de la Merced 
Transport for London, the city’s transportation regulator, said on Friday that it would not renew the ride-hailing service’s operating license when it expires on Sept. 30.
The regulator, known as TfL, said in a statement on Twitter that it had concluded that Uber was “not fit and proper” to hold a private-hire operator license.
It also argued that Uber had demonstrated a “lack of corporate responsibility in relation to a number of issues.”
The regulator’s complaints also touched on:
•The company’s approach to reporting serious criminal offenses,
• Its approach to background checks on drivers for the service, and
• Uber’s explanations about how it used Greyball software to prevent regulators from gaining full access to the app.
Worth noting: Uber will appeal the decision, and can keep operating in London throughout the process.
From a statement by an Uber spokesman:
“Uber operates in more than 600 cities around the world, including more than 40 towns and cities here in the UK. This ban would show the world that, far from being open, London is closed to innovative companies who bring choice to consumers.”
Joe Murphy, the political editor of London’s Evening Standard newspaper, had this to say on Twitter: “Uber employs 40,000 drivers in London alone. That’s like closing a town.”
Related Reading
The Wall Street Journal’s Greg Bensinger says that Benchmark, one of Uber’s earliest backers, won’t participate in a plan to let SoftBank buy out existing investors."

Alsup has a history of being a very difficult Judge before whom to argue patent cases. His tendency seems to require a substantially stronger burden of proof of actual infringement upon a tangible device and seems to lean towards the belief that intangible ideas or concepts should not be patent-able. I think this clearly puts Waymo at a disadvantage, and they may have been better off trying to pursue a trade secrets violation if they could find some evidentiary support.
Both sides are having public controversies and so there is an incentive to settle

Unlikely to be in Waymo's interests to settle quickly. Number of depositions and complexity are increasing (Benchmark Capital lawsuit against Kalanick). Likely huge technical reports to document transfer of ideas

Google will push to have this moved quickly and an outcome will be resolved before the July 1 2018 date.

The case of Google owned Waymo vs. Uber, Ottomotto and Ottotrucking contains four major complaints which amount to theft of trade secrets, patent infringement and fraud.  The complaint from the above link is relatively straightforward.  In a previous case under Judge Alsup, Anthony Levandowski pleaded the fifth when asked if he stole trade secrets from Waymo, created Otto and sold Otto to Uber for $680 million dollars six month later.  The complaint is well written and the evidence so overwhelming, it seems as if the matter is how much the settlement will be instead of the results of a jury trial.

Most patent lawsuits in Silicon Valley end in settlement.  That's my base rate.  On top of that,  Uber investors is in house cleaning mode right now, with CEO stepping down.  You'd think Uber is highly motivated.  On the other hand, it is not a slam dunk -- unclear what terms would Waymo accept.

When researching the case, I found the exact details of what occurred. The case explicitly states a former Google (Waymo) employee secretly downloaded 14,000 files, created a self driving car startup, then had that startup bought by Uber. "The complaint very specifically names the ways in which Levandowski stole the data." as said in the case file. The case was brought up in February 2017, giving Uber and Google almost a year and a half to either settle, or have Uber be found liable. When reading up on These types of lawsuits I found "In order to win a trade secret misappropriation suit in most states, the trade secret owner will need to show that the information at issue qualifies as a trade secret. It must be secret information that confers a competitive advantage and was the subject of reasonable efforts to maintain its secrecy. Also, the defendant must have improperly acquired the information or improperly disclosed it. Improper acquisition methods include espionage, fraud, theft, and bribery. Improper disclosure usually occurs when the person disclosing or publishing the information has reason to know it was improperly acquired." which seems to fall directly under what is happening. Also when reading more up on the settlement itself, I found that "Uber’s attorney told investors that a lawsuit over self-driving cars from Alphabet’s Waymo could be settled before a scheduled court date in October, though she said no formal agreement is in the works, said the people, who asked not to be identified because the information is private." according to Bloomberg. Although one could be lying to investors to show this isn't as big of a deal as it may seem. According to the same article, money is growing for Uber, so settling may be the right decision to clear the waters with all the scandals happening within the firm.
Northern District of California is a slow court and most cases end up in settlement. (source:http://tiny.cc/j0anmy)
Lawyers can make this stretch out. No reason to settle now. I believe the timeframe is short for this type of case and that there ample reasons to let this continue to stretch out.
I think Uber has crossed many lines of ethical practices and bent the law to their advantage.
They are guilty but I am unsure about the time frame.
The legal processes will take longer than a year to get to settlement stage.
